question:
Consider the (toy) grammar $G$ consisting of the following rules:
R1: S --> NP VP
R2: NP --> NN
R3: NP --> Det NN
R4: NN --> N
R5: NN --> NN NN
R6: NN --> NN PNP
R7: PNP --> Prep NP
R8: VP --> V
R9: VP --> Adv V
What type of rules does the provided grammar $G$ consist of?
What type of rules should $G$ be complemented with to be exploitable in practice?
What is the format of these missing rules?
answer:
G consists of syntactic rules.
G should be complemented with lexical rules with the following format:
T --> w, where T is a pre-terminal (i.e. a Part-of-Speech tag) and w is a terminal (i.e. a word).

question: State Evolution for the RFIM: Our aim in this exercise is to provide an algorithm for finding the lowest energy configuration, and to analyse its property. 1. Using the variational approach of lecture 1 , section 1.3 or the cavity method of section 1.4, explain why the following iterative algorithm might be a good one for finding the lowest energy in practice: $$ S_i^{t+1}=\operatorname{sign}\left(h_i+\frac{1}{N} \sum_i S_i^t\right) $$
answer:
Similar to what we did in exercise 1.5 , we start by looking at the Hamiltonian of our model, collecting all the terms that have an explicit dependence on spin $i$ : $$  egin{aligned} \mathcal{H}_N\left(S_i ;\{S\}_{j 
eq i},\{h\}ight) & =- rac{N}{2}\left(\sum_{j 
eq i}  rac{S_j}{N}+ rac{S_i}{N}ight)^2-\sum_{j 
eq i} h_j S_j-h_i S_i \ & =	ext { const }-\left(\sum_{\mathrm{j} 
eq \mathrm{i}}  rac{\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{j}}}{\mathrm{N}}+\mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{i}}ight) \mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{i}} \epsilonnd{aligned} $$ We now look for a mean-field approximation of the associated Boltzmann-Gibbs measure: starting from a fully-connected model, where each spin interacts with all the other spins, we would like to approximate our probability measure with a factorized probability, i.e. (showing only the dependence on the spins): $$ P\left(\{S\}_{i=1}^Night) \approx \prod_{i=1}^N Q_{M F}\left(S_iight) $$ where each spin feels the external magnetic field $h_i$, plus a mean-field interaction term that approximates the two-body interaction of the RFIM. In this model we can conveniently approximate: $$ \sum_{j 
eq i}  rac{S_j}{N}=\sum_j  rac{S_j}{N}+O\left( rac{1}{N}ight) $$ and replace the interaction by an effective field of intensity $ ar{S}$, equal for all spins. Now our approximate model is fully factorized: $$ Q_{M F}\left(S_i, h_i,  ar{S} ;  etaight)= rac{e^{ eta\left(h_i+ ar{S}ight) S_i}}{2 \cosh \left( eta\left(h_i+ ar{S}ight)ight)} . $$ Notice that this is exactly what we used for the sequential Glauber dynamics, in the first homework. Now, we know that the Boltzmann-Gibbs measure peaks on the minima of the energy when the temperature is sent to 0 , i.e. when $ eta ightarrow \infty$. If we take the same limit in our factorized probability distribution, we immediately see that the probability for each spin will become a Kronecker's $\delta$, depending only on the sign of the local field: $$ Q_{M F}\left(S_i=Sight) \stackrel{ eta ightarrow \infty}{=} \delta_{S, \operatorname{sign}\left(h_i+ ar{S}ight)} . $$ This suggests us a greedy algorithm (i.e., working directly at zero temperature) for descending our discrete energy landscape: align each spin with the corresponding local field, recompute the effective field, and iterate: $$ S_i^{(t+1)}=\operatorname{sign}\left(h_i+\sum_{j=1}^N S_j^{(t)}ight) $$ In general, greedy optimization algorithms are prone to getting trapped in local minima, but we will see in the following that in this case the algorithm works like a charm.

question: Prove that √2 is irrational.
answer:
Assume that √2 is rational, i.e. √2 = a/b where a,b are coprime (have no common divisors).
We square both sides, thus 2 = a^2/b^2 → a^2 = 2b^2. Therefore, a^2 is even, and using the result of the previous exercise we know that a is even. Since a is even, it has the form a=2k. We substitute this in the previous equation and we have that: (2k)^2 = 2b^2 → 4k2 = 2b^2 → b^2 = 2k2. Since b^2 = 2k^2, this means that b2 is even → b is even, which is a contradiction! The contradiction is that we assumed a,b to be coprime, but we concluded that both are even!

question: Can plasma promote epithelialization: the process enabling the covering of denuded epithelial surface?
answer: Yes: superficial wounds realized on forearms of volunteer patients can be improved in terms of aesthetic recovery using the kINPen plasma source. Short-term plasma stimulation, repeatedly applied for 3 days, corresponds to be the most effective wound treatment.
choices: No: the cellular and molecular processes involved in initiation, maintenance, and completion of epithelialization do not depend on environmental stress caused by plasma exposure. The wound closure follows the same mechanisms as in any control group.

Yes: superficial wounds realized on forearms of volunteer patients can be improved in terms of aesthetic recovery using the kINPen plasma source. Short-term plasma stimulation, repeatedly applied for 3 days, corresponds to be the most effective wound treatment.

Yes: superficial wounds realized on forearms of volunteer patients can be improved in terms of aesthetic recovery using the kINPen plasma source. Single long-term plasma stimulation corresponds to be the most effective wound treatment.
explanation: To show the potential of cold plasma on skin epithelialization, an experiment has been performed on superficial wounds present on forearms of volunteer patients. Upon this experiment, the wounds were treated using the kINPen plasma source and considering three different time exposures: 10 s/day upon 3 days, 10 s/day upon 1 day and 30 s/day upon 1 day. It turns out that 10 days later, the short-term plasma stimulation, repeatedly applied for 3 days, looks to be the most effective in terms of aesthetic recovery. Generally, in plasma medicine, it is often necessary to favor several short-term plasma exposures at a single longer exposure.

question: How is termed the fraction of attenuated incident photons per unit thickness of a material?
answer: Linear attenuation coefficient
explanation: It is expressed numerically in units of \(\textrm{cm}^{-1}\) and it represents the fraction of photons removed from a monoenergetic beam per unit thickness of material. The mass attenuation coefficient is a normalisation of the linear attenuation coefficient per unit density of a material.

question:
A lighthouse is placed close to a straight coastline at a position lpha along the shore and a 
          distance  eta out to the sea. The distance  eta is known, but the position lpha is not known.  
          The lighthouse emits a series of short flashes at random intervals and hence in random directions 
          (uniformly at random over the full angle of 2\pi). These pulses are intercepted on the coast by photo-detectors that 
          record only the fact that a flash has occurred, but not the angle from which it came. N flashes have been recorded so 
          far at positions x_k , k = 1, ... , N . 
          Goal: From the N observations x = \{x_k\}_{k=1}^N estimate the position of the lighthouse lpha. 
          Use the Bayes formula to express the probability P (lpha|  eta, x) that lpha has a given value conditioned on 
          the value of  eta and the N observations x.
answer: P(lpha| eta, \{x_k\}_{k=1}^N) \propto P( \{x_k\}_{k=1}^N | lpha,  eta) P(lpha |  eta) = \prod_{k=1}^N P(x_k | lpha,  eta)P(lpha|  eta)

question:
Consider the following algorithm 	extsc{Random-Check} that takes as input two subsets $S\subseteq E$ and $T\subseteq E$ of the same ground set $E$.  egin{center}  egin{boxedminipage}[t]{0.85	extwidth} 	extsc{Random-Check}$(S,T)$ \[2mm] 1.  For each element $e\in E$, independently of other elements randomly set  egin{align*} x_e =  egin{cases} 1 & \mbox{with probability $1/3$} \ 0 & \mbox{with probability $2/3$} \end{cases} \end{align*} 2. \IF $\sum_{e\in S} x_e = \sum_{e\in T} x_e$ \THEN \[1mm] 3. \qquad \RETURN  true \[1mm] 4. \ELSE\ 5. \qquad \RETURN false \end{boxedminipage} \end{center} Note that 	extsc{Random-Check}$(S,T)$ returns true with probability $1$ if $S=T$. Your task is to analyze the probability that the algorithm returns true if $S 
eq T$. Specifically prove that 	extsc{Random-Check}$(S,T)$ returns true with probability at most $2/3$ if $S
eq T$.\ {\em (In this problem you are asked to prove that 	extsc{Random-Check}($S,T$) returns true with probability at most $2/3$ if $S 
eq T$.    Recall that you are allowed to refer to material covered in the lecture notes.)}
answer:
We solve the problem using "deferred decision" technique. First, note that simply one has $$\sum_{e\in S}x_e=\sum_{e\in S\setminus T}x_e +\sum_{e\in S\cap T} x_e$$ and $$\sum_{e\in T}x_e=\sum_{e\in T\setminus S}x_e +\sum_{e\in T\cap S} x_e.$$ So, we have $$\Pr\left[\sum_{e\in S}x_e=\sum_{e\in T}x_e\mid S
e Tight]=\Pr\left[\sum_{e\in S\setminus T}x_e=\sum_{e\in T\setminus S}x_e\mid S
e Tight].$$ Note that since $S
e T$, then $(S\setminus T)\cup (T\setminus S)
e \emptyset$, and therefore $\exists f \in (S\setminus T)\cup (T\setminus S)$. Without lose of generality suppose that $f\in (S\setminus T)$. Then, $$Pr\left[\sum_{e\in S\setminus T}x_e=\sum_{e\in T\setminus S}x_e\mid S
e Tight]=Pr\left[ x_f=\sum_{e\in T\setminus S}x_e-\sum_{e\in (S\setminus T)\setminus \{f\}}x_e\mid S
e Tight].$$ At this point, assume that we know that values of $x_e$'s for all $e\in E\setminus \{f\}$, so $c:=\sum_{e\in T\setminus S}x_e-\sum_{e\in (S\setminus T)\setminus \{f\}}x_e$ is fixed. We just need to note that $\Pr\left[x_f=c |S
e Tight]=\Pr\left[x_f=c ight]\le  rac{2}{3}$ for any $c\in \mathbb{R}$ by assumption of the question (line 1 of 	extsc{Random-Check($S,T$)}). So, the claim holds.

question:

          Hint: Recall that if one has a random variable A with probability distribution P(A) and one needs to express a probability 
          distribution of a random variable B = f(A), where f is some known function, one can use \int P(A)\delta [B-f(A)]dA, 
          where \delta() is the Dirac delta function. The integral over B can then be computed by substitution f(A) ightarrow D 
          and using the definition of a Dirac delta that states g(C) = \int dD\delta(C-D)g(D) for any test function g.
answer:
Let's consider a uniform distribution over the angle 	heta_k, i.e. P(	heta_k|lpha,  eta) = (1 / \pi). 
          Expressing the position x_k as a function of the angle 	heta_k: x_k =  eta tan 	heta_k + lpha. Then 
          P(x_k|lpha,  eta ) = \int  rac{1}{\pi} \delta (x_k - [ eta tan 	heta_k + lpha]) d	heta_k. 
          Let D =  eta tan 	heta_k + lpha , dD =  eta(tan^2 	heta_k + 1)d	heta_k =  eta (( rac{D-lpha}{ eta})^2 + 1)d	heta_k, 
           P(x_k | lpha,  eta) =  rac{1}{\pi} \int  rac{\delta(x_k - D)}{ eta(( rac{D-lpha}{ eta})+ 1)}dD =  rac{1}{\pi} rac{1}{ eta(( rac{x_k-lpha}{ eta})+ 1)} =  rac{ eta}{\pi [ eta^2 + (x_k - lpha)^2]}.

question: Why can we conclude from  the relation between \(V_L\), \(V_R\), and \(l\) which we have just derived that the plasma particles perfectly follow the perturbations of the magnetic field lines?
answer: While the magnetic field perturbation travels to the right, the magnetic field lines move vertically with a velocity \(  -c_Al' \). This equals the vertical velocity of the plasma we have just derived
choices: While the magnetic field perturbation travels to the right, the magnetic field lines move vertically with a velocity \(  -c_Al' \). This equals the vertical velocity of the plasma we have just derived

As we have assumed that \(B_{1y}  \) has only a contribution traveling to the right, the same is true for \(V_{1y}  \), and the plasma particles therefore perfectly follow the transverse displacment of the  magnetic field lines
explanation: The vertical movement of the magnetic field lines is given by \( -c_Al' \). We can see this for example by noting that the vertical movement of a field lines is given by \(\partial l(z-c_At)/\partial t\), and this indeed equals \( (-c_A)l'  \). As we found that \(V_{1y}=V_L(z+c_At)+V_R(z-c_At)=0-c_Al'  \), we have demonstrated that the plasma moves vertically with the same velocity as the magnetic field lines.

question: Soit $A = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ b & d \end{pmatrix}$ et la forme quadratique $Q(x) = x^T A x.$ Montrez que\begin{enumerate}[a)] \item $Q$ est définie positive si $\det A > 0$ et $a>0$; \item $Q$ est définie négative si $\det A > 0$ et $a<0$; \item $Q$ est indéfinie si $\det A < 0$.\end{enumerate}
answer: {Calculons le polynôme characteristique de la matrice $A$\begin{align}\label{eq:polchar_1} \det(\lambda I - A) = \lambda^2 - \lambda \tr A + \det A = \lambda^2 - (a+d) \lambda + (ad - b^2).\end{align}Le théorème spectral pour les matrices symétriques indique que la matrice $A$ a deux valeurs propres réelles $\lambda_1, \lambda_2$ (où $\lambda_1 = \lambda_2$ est possible). En utilisant $\lambda_1, \lambda_2$, le polynôme characteristique de $A$ est représenté par\begin{align}\label{eq:polchar_2} \det(\lambda I - A) = (\lambda - \lambda_1) (\lambda - \lambda_2) = \lambda^2 - (\lambda_1 + \lambda_2) \lambda + \lambda_1 \lambda_2,\end{align}donc, en comparant les coéfficients de~\eqref{eq:polchar_1} et~\eqref{eq:polchar_2}, nous déduisons\begin{align*} \tr A = \lambda_1 + \lambda_2, \qquad \det A = \lambda_1 \lambda_2.\end{align*}\begin{enumerate}[a)] \item $Q$ est définie positive si et seulement si toutes les valeurs propres de $A$ sont strictement positives.  Comme $\det A = \lambda_1 \lambda_2 > 0$, nous observons que ou $\lambda_1, \lambda_2 > 0$ ou $\lambda_1, \lambda_2 < 0$, donc les valeurs propres sont de même signe.  Comme $\det A = ad -b^2 > 0$ et $a>0$ il est nécessaire que $d>0$, donc $0 < a + d = \tr A = \lambda_1 + \lambda_2$.  En fait, ça permet à conclure que $\lambda_1, \lambda_2 > 0$. \item $Q$ est définie négative si et seulement si toutes les valuers propres de $A$ sont strictement négatives.  Comme dans la partie a) nous déduisons de $\det A > 0$ que $\lambda_1, \lambda_2$ sont de même signe.  Mais par contre, $\det A = ad - b^2 > 0$ et $a < 0$ implique que $d < 0$ est nécessaire. Alors, comme $0 > a + d = \tr A = \lambda_1 + \lambda_2$ on obtient que $\lambda_1, \lambda_2 < 0$. \item $Q$ est indéfinie si et seulement si $A$ a des valeurs propres négatives et positives.  De $\lambda_1 \lambda_2 = \det A < 0$ nous déduisons directement que $\lambda_1, \lambda_2$ sont de signes différents.\end{enumerate}}

question: MoS2 and WSe2 are transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), which belong to the class of 2D materials. This means that they can be separated into atomically thin layers. What type of band gap do you expect in bilayer WSe2 under 1.52% strain?
answer: As increasing strain is applied to the WSe2 bilayer, the phololuminescence peak shifts towards higher energies and increases in intensity, resembling the peak from the monolayer. This indicates that by applying strain, we can shift the bands to have a direct bandgap in WSe2 bilayers.

question: Given the dual function $d(\lambda):=\min _{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^p} \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{x}, \lambda)$, show that weak duality always holds. (HINT: Recall that weak duality means that $f\left(\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right) \geq d\left(\lambda^{\star}\right)$.)
answer:
$$
f\left(x^*\right)=\min _x \max _\lambda \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{x}, \lambda) \geq \max _\lambda \min _{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^p} \mathcal{L}(\mathbf{x}, \lambda)=\max _\lambda d(\lambda)=d\left(\lambda^{\star}\right)
$$
where the inequality is due to the fact that min max is lower bounded by max min.

question: Soient $A$ et $B$ des matrices $n \times n$.Montrer les affirmations suivantes.Si $A$ et $B$ sont des matrices triangulaires inf\'erieures (resp.sup\'erieures), alors le produit $AB$ est aussi une matrice triangulaireinf\'erieure (resp. sup\'erieure).
answer: {Soient les coefficients des matrices $A$ et $B$ donn\'es respectivement par$(a_{ij})_{i,j=1}^n$ et $(b_{ij})_{i,j=1}^n$. Comme $A$ et $B$ sonttriangulaires inf\'erieures, on a $a_{ij}=0$ si $j>i$ et $b_{ij}=0$ si $j>i$.Supposons $j>i$ et calculons\[(AB)_{ij} = \sum_{k=1}^n a_{ik}b_{kj} = \sum_{k=1}^{i} a_{ik}b_{kj} + \sum_{k=i+1}^n a_{ik}b_{kj} = 0,\]car d'une part $b_{kj}=0$ lorsque $1 \leq k \leq i < j$, et d'autre part $a_{ik}=0$ lorsque $i < k\leq n$.Ainsi, $AB$ est triangulaire inf\'erieure. Le même raisonnement s'applique pour les matrices triangulaires supérieures. On traite le cas de matrices \(A\) et $B$ triangulaires sup\'erieures de manière similaire.\\Pour les matrices triangulaires supérieures, on peut refaire un calculsemblable. Mais on peut aussi utiliser ce qui vient d'être démontré en utilisant l'opération de \emph{transposition}, qui transforme une matrice triangulairesupérieure en une matrice triangulaire inférieure, et vice versa. En effet, soient $A$ et $B$ des matrices triangulaires sup\'erieures.Alors $AB=((AB)^T)^T=(B^TA^T)^T$. Comme $B^TA^T$ est un produit de matricestriangulaires inférieures, c'est une matrice triangulaire inférieure, et donc$AB$ est triangulaire sup\'erieure.}

question: In this exercise, we will see how to combine the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and the kernel method into an algorithm known as kernel PCA. We are given $n$ observations in a low dimensional space $\mathbf{x}_{1}, \cdots, \mathbf{x}_{n} \in \mathbb{R}^{L}$ and we consider a kernel $k$ and its associated features $\operatorname{map} \phi: \mathbb{R}^{L} \mapsto \mathbb{R}^{H}$ which satisfies: $$ k(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})=\langle\phi(\mathbf{x}), \phi(\mathbf{y})\rangle_{\mathbb{R}^{H}} $$ where $\langle\cdot, \cdot\rangle_{\mathbb{R}^{H}}$ is the standard scalar product of $\mathbb{R}^{H}$. We define the empirical covariance matrix and the empirical covariance matrix of the mapped observations as: $$ \boldsymbol{\Sigma}:=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbf{x}_{i} \mathbf{x}_{i}^{\top} \quad \text { and } \quad \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\mathbf{H}}:=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right) \phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)^{\top} $$ The kernel matrix $\mathbf{K}$ is defined by: $$ \mathbf{K}_{i, j}:=k\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}, \mathbf{x}_{j}\right)=\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right), \phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{j}\right)\right\rangle_{\mathbb{R}^{H}} $$ We also define the data matrix and the corresponding matrix of the mapped data as: $$ \mathbf{X}:=\left(\begin{array}{c} \mathbf{x}_{1}^{\top} \\ \cdots \\ \mathbf{x}_{n}^{\top} \end{array}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times L} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbf{\Phi}:=\left(\begin{array}{c} \phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{1}\right)^{\top} \\ \cdots \\ \phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{n}\right)^{\top} \end{array}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times H} . $$ Finally we denote the eigenpairs (eigenvalues and eigenvectors) of $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\mathbf{H}}$ by $\left\{\left(\lambda_{i}, \mathbf{v}_{i}\right)\right\}_{i=1}^{H}$ and those of $\mathbf{K}$ by $\left\{\left(\rho_{j}, \mathbf{w}_{j}\right)\right\}_{j=1}^{n}$. We also assume that the vectors $\mathbf{v}_{i}$ and $\mathbf{w}_{j}$ are normalized. Thus: $$ \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\mathbf{H}} \mathbf{v}_{i}=\lambda_{i} \mathbf{v}_{i}, \quad\left\|\mathbf{v}_{i}\right\|_{2}=1 \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbf{K} \mathbf{w}_{j}=\rho_{j} \mathbf{w}_{j}, \quad\left\|\mathbf{w}_{j}\right\|_{2}=1 $$ Let us remind that we assume in the kernel setting that we can compute $k(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})$ but that we cannot directly compute $\phi(\mathbf{x})$ What we would like to do is to first map the data into the high-dimensional space using the features map $\phi$ and then to apply the standard PCA algorithm in the high-dimensional space $\mathbb{R}^{H}$. This would amount to: (a) Computing the empirical covariance matrix $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\mathbf{H}}$ of the mapped data $\phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)$. (b) Computing the eigenvectors $\mathbf{v}_{1}, \cdots, \mathbf{v}_{N}$ associated with the $N$ largest eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\mathbf{H}}$. (c) Computing the projection $\Pi\left(\phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{L}$ for each data point onto these eigenvectors, where the $j$-th component of the projection is given by: $$ \Pi_{j}\left(\phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right)=\left\langle\phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right), \mathbf{v}_{j}\right\rangle_{\mathbb{R}^{H}} $$ Explain why we cannot directly apply the algorithm explained above.
answer: We assume that we cannot directly compute $\phi(\mathbf{x})$. The complexity would be too high. Instead, we will now apply the kernel trick to this problem:

question: Vrai ou faux?
answer:
Si \(a_n\lt x_n\lt  b_n\) pour tout \(n\) suffisamment grand, et si 
\(a_n\to L\) et \(b_n\to L\), alors \(x_n\to L\).

Si il existe \(N_1\) tel que \(x_n\geq a_n\) pour tout \(n\geq N_1\)
et s'il existe \(N_2\) tel que \(x_n\leq b_n\) pour tout \(n\geq N_2\), 
et si \(a_n\) et \(b_n\) convergent vers la même limite, alors \(x_n\) est
convergente.
choices:
Si \(a_n\leq x_n\leq  b_n\) pour tout \(n\) suffisamment grand, et si
\(x_n\) ne converge pas, alors \(a_n\) et \(b_n\) ne convergent pas non plus.
Si \(a_n\lt x_n\lt  b_n\) pour tout \(n\) suffisamment grand, et si 
\(a_n\to L\) et \(b_n\to L\), alors \(x_n\to L\).
Si \(a_n\leq x_n\leq  b_n\) pour tout \(n\) suffisamment grand, et si 
\(|a_n-b_n|\to 0\), alors \(x_n\) converge.
Si il existe \(N_1\) tel que \(x_n\geq a_n\) pour tout \(n\geq N_1\)
et s'il existe \(N_2\) tel que \(x_n\leq b_n\) pour tout \(n\geq N_2\), 
et si \(a_n\) et \(b_n\) convergent vers la même limite, alors \(x_n\) est
convergente.
Si \(a_n\leq x_n\leq b_n\) pour tout \(n\) suffisamment grand, et si
\(\limninfty a_n\neq \limninfty b_n\), alors \(x_n\) n'a pas de limite.
Si \(|x_n|\leq n\) et si \(y_n\to 0\), alors \(x_ny_n\to 0\).
Si \(e^{x_n}\) est bornée et si \(y_n\to 0\), alors \(x_ny_n\to 0\).

question: Montrer qu'un produit de matrices \(n\times n\) triangulaires inférieures esttriangulaire inférieur.
answer: {Soient \(A=(a_{ij})\) et \(B=(b_{ij})\) deux matrices\(n\times n\) triangulaires inférieures, c'est-à-dire telles que \(a_{ij}=b_{ij}=0\) si \(j<i\).Le coefficient \(ij\) du produit \(AB\) est donné par\[ (AB)_{ij}=\sum_{\ell=1}^na_{i\ell}b_{\ell j}\,.\]Comme \(A\) et \(B\) sont triangulaires supérieures, on a\(b_{\ell j}=0\) pour les \(\ell=1,\dots,j-1\) et\(a_{i\ell}=0\) pour les \(\ell=i+1,\dots,n\). Donc, si l'on prend une paire d'indices \(ij\) pour laquelle \(j>i\), on aura \(a_{i\ell}b_{\ell j}=0\) pour tout \(\ell=1,\dots,n\), et donc \(c_{ij}=0\). Ceci montre que \(AB\) est triangulaire supérieure.\\Pour un produit quelconque de matrices triangulaires supérieures \(A_1,\dots,A_n\), on procède par récurrence: on a montré ci-dessus que \(A_1A_2\) est triangulaire supérieure, donc \(A_1A_2A_3=(A_1A_2)A_3\) l'est aussi, etc.}

question: Parmi ces affirmations, lesquelles sont toujours vraies?
answer:
Si \(f:]a,b[\to \bR\) est telle que \(f'(x)=0\) pour pour tout \(x\in
]a,b[\), alors \(f(x_1)=f(x_2)\) pour toute paire \(x_1,x_2\in ]a,b[\).
choices:
Si \(f:\bR\to \bR\) est constante sur chaque intervalle de la forme
\([n,n+1[\) (\(n\in \bZ\)), 
alors \(f'(x)=0\) pour tout \(x\in \bR\).

Si \(f\) est dérivable sur un ouvert \(D\), et si \(f'(x)=0\) pour
tout \(x\in D\), alors \(f\) est une constante.

Si \(f:]a,b[\to \bR\) est telle que \(f'(x)=0\) pour pour tout \(x\in
]a,b[\), alors \(f(x_1)=f(x_2)\) pour toute paire \(x_1,x_2\in ]a,b[\).
